posts.name:
Walter Crosby
Walter Crosby
posts.content:
Not making progress is something that drives entrepreneurs nuts.

Having to solve the same problem repeatedly for salespeople is one of the things I hear a lot. They come to you looking for you to solve their problem or answer a simple question.

Here is my recommendation - stop giving them the answer. Let me explain.

They bring you problems because you solve them. Create a habit of asking them 5 questions before you answer.

1) Have you ever encountered this problem before?
2) What did you do that time?
3) Did that work?
4) Why or Why not?
5) How is this problem the same or different?
6) What do you think you should do this time?

Help them solve their problem and they will own the answer, and you can go celebrate with a cigar.

comments.commentText: I recommend trying this exercise a couple of times. Be conversational. Be interested. Be patient. It works with teenagers too.

posts.name:
Jess V.
Jess V.
posts.content:
What the what? 
What does ENSHITTIFICATION mean? . . . Well, we are living it  

Doctorow explains that platforms initially provide high-quality services to attract users. Once a substantial user base is established, the platform begins to prioritize business customers, often at the expense of user experience. Eventually, the platform focuses on maximizing profits for shareholders, leading to further degradation of service quality for both users and business customers (Netflix is a great example of this).

This concept has gained recognition, with the American Dialect Society selecting "enshittification" as its 2023 Word of the Year, and the Macquarie Dictionary following suit for 2024.

Perhaps, unironically, the
Word of the Year (a branch of my favorite dictionary - the
, because yes, I'm a geek like that) is:

 brain rot

Defined as, "the supposed deterioration of a personas mental or intellectual state, especially viewed as a result of overconsumption of material (now particularly online content) considered to be trivial or unchallenging. Also: something characterized as likely to lead to such deterioration."

What platforms do you see enshittification front and center right now?

P.S.
This may be one of my favorite words to say right now. Some words just slide off the tongue, like "serendipity" and "defenestration" (I jokingly threaten my kids with that one all the time )


#2024

posts.name:
Mezanur Rahman
Mezanur Rahman
posts.content:
"Social Media Treasure Hunt"
Objective: Increase brand awareness, engage your audience, and drive social media interaction.
How it Works:
1.     Announce the Treasure Hunt:
o  Create a compelling post on your social media channels to announce the start of the treasure hunt.
o  Explain that participants will need to follow clues to find hidden messages or codes on your website or social media pages.
2.     Create Clues and Challenges:
o  Develop a series of fun and intriguing clues related to your products, services, or brand values.
o  Share these clues over a period of days or weeks on different social media platforms (e.g., Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn).
3.     Engage with Participants:
o  Encourage participants to like, share, and comment on the posts to increase engagement.
o  Offer hints or additional clues in response to user interactions to keep the activity lively and interactive.
4.     Hidden Messages/Codes:
o  Hide messages or codes on your website or social media pages. These could be found in blog posts, product descriptions, or behind images.
o  Each hidden message or code should lead to the next clue or be part of a larger puzzle.
5.     Rewards and Incentives:
o  Offer attractive rewards for participants who complete the treasure hunt. These could include discounts, freebies, or exclusive access to new products.
o  Announce winners on your social media channels and encourage them to share their experiences.
6.     Measure and Analyze:
o  Track engagement metrics, such as likes, shares, comments, and website traffic, to measure the success of the campaign.
o  Collect feedback from participants to understand what they enjoyed and how you can improve future activities.
Benefits:
Increases brand visibility and awareness.
Encourages user-generated content and word-of-mouth promotion.
Strengthens community engagement and loyalty.
Provides valuable insights into customer preferences and behavior.

posts.name:
Raglan Tribe
Raglan Tribe
posts.content:
I have spent 21 years consulting Toyota, Hyundai and Siemens and I hear this one sentence all the time from tech companies:

"Our technology is too advanced - customers don't understand it."

They think their biggest challenge is product complexity.

They're wrong.

The real problem:

Engineers mistake technical capability for market value.

In one automotive project, the team had created remarkable autonomous driving features. Yet sales were stagnant.

Because they focused on explaining how it worked rather than why it mattered.

We implemented a three-phase solution:

1)Map capability to customer pain points

2)Translate technical features into business outcomes

3)Build proof cases showing direct value impact

Take one client's autonomous system. Instead of detailing sensor arrays and algorithms, we showed how it reduced fleet accidents by 43% and cut insurance costs by 38%.

Sales pipeline grew 5x in six months. Same technology, completely different story.

In technology selling, the gap isn't technical understanding - it's value translation.

comments.commentText: Attracted by the emerging technologies, it’s easy to lose sight of the core principle that the foundation of any successful product lies in addressing customer pain points. The most impactful businesses often begin by identifying and solving real problems, as highlighted in one of the YC lessons for founders. Starting with a solution in search of a problem—such as jumping onto buzzwords like blockchain or generative AI and then scrambling to build a business case—can be an expensive and inefficient approach. Prioritising the customer’s needs over technology hype is key to building truly effective solutions.
Or brag about it this way rather than with technical charts. Amiright, Brittany Tessmer and Tessmer Jeffrey https://usa.nissanstories.com/en-US/releases/technology-1-tension-0

posts.name:
John Kraski
John Kraski
posts.content:
You know how super-hot and attractive people get lots of likes and fire emojis on Instagram for nothing other than being super-hot and attractive?

You always wonder why they are successful.

Well they understand their audience.

Well, that’s me on LinkedIn.

But l make my community thirsty in a different way.

I load them up with super sexy billboards with stale quotes and generic motivational advice on whiteboards.

This how you deliver real impact on LinkedIn.

Stay thirsty my friends.

comments.commentText:
John Kraski this is interesting because it points to something bigger: attention is currency.

Some people spend it quickly on flashy quotes, slick images, or loud opinions. 

Others save it for things that build connection and trust over time.

Neither is right or wrong, it just depends on what you want to create.

For me, the real art is knowing your audience well enough to give them something they didn’t even realize they needed. That’s where the impact lives.

Your post reminds me that grabbing attention is easy, but what you do with it? That’s where it gets real.
Great callout Isabelle LaCroix Vienneau CRP !
Haha Natalie Leal Blanco ! Me too! About to drop a Thomas Woodhams Oaty shoutout!
John Kraski you’ll make me more thirsty

comments.commentText:
I am writing to highlight my repeated unpleasant experiences with Swiggy. As a loyal Zomato user, I recently decided to try Swiggy after enrolling in Swiggy Black. Unfortunately, my experiences have been consistently disappointing, and the issues are recurring.

I placed an order at 7:00 PM for my 5-year-old daughter, who is unwell. The initial estimated delivery time was 25 minutes. However, 1.5 hours later, the order had still not been delivered.

When I reached out to Swiggy’s support team, they extended the delivery time repeatedly, without any meaningful resolution.

Despite knowing this, Swiggy failed to notify me or take corrective action. Instead, they continued to delay the delivery time and offered a Rs. 100 voucher valid for just two days, which felt insincere and dismissive of the situation.

In contrast, I have never encountered such issues with Zomato, which has consistently provided reliable and prompt service. I strongly urge Swiggy to address these systemic problems, improve its delivery process, and show genuine concern for customers. Until these issues are resolved, I advise potential users to reconsider using Swiggy.

Sriharsha M., Swiggy Cares And Swiggy Is this the level of service I should expect? Such harassment and nuisance. I requested a replacement yesterday, yet all I’ve been told is to email support or that my feedback will be passed on.

It seems you don’t understand the gravity of the situation. I ordered PLANT-BASED MOMO RAMEN and was sent CHICKEN MOMOS instead.

Sending an entirely wrong order gives me the right to demand a full refund and further compensation for the harassment I’ve been dealing with since yesterday. No one has provided a solution, no one was willing to call, no one listened, and even now, no one seems ready to address the issue. This is completely unacceptable.

This complete lack of professionalism and accountability has caused me significant mental stress. As a paying customer, I expect proper service, respect for my dietary preferences, and immediate resolution. Incidents like this destroy trust in your brand and impact your reputation.

I demand a full refund and additional compensation for the mental stress caused by this ordeal. If I do not receive a resolution within 24 hours, I will escalate the matter to social media and consumer forums.
